metadata.case_name: East & West Steamship Co. etc. v. Consignees
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal Nos. 88 of 1956, 91 of 1958 and 92 of 1958

facts.text: 90 bundles of brass circles consigned from Bombay to Madras per S.S. Fakira, arrived Madras on August 1, 1948.
78 bundles delivered on August 25, 1948, to appellant through clearing agent.
5 more bundles delivered on September 25, 1948; 7 bundles not delivered.
Shipping company repudiated claim on March 24, 1950.
Suit filed on June 27, 1950, for Rs. 1,023-5-0 (Rs. 974-13-0 for goods, Rs. 48-8-0 profit; profit claim abandoned).
Small Causes Court, Madras, dismissed suit on November 2, 1951; new trial application dismissed.
Madras High Court in CRP 921/1952 remanded suit on February 11, 1954.
After remand, Small Causes Court decreed suit for Rs. 974-13-0 on May 4, 1954; no further steps by shipping company then, special leave granted October 11, 1954; decree final.

Consignments to Bombay per S.S. Tweedsmuir Park, S.S. Finnamore Hill, S.S. Ismalia (British India Steam Navigation Co.); arrived September 10, 1948 (Tweedsmuir, Finnamore), September 6, 1948 (Ismalia).
Discharged to Bombay docks; short delivery: 164 bags (Ismalia), 869 bags (Finnamore), 1,657 bags (Tweedsmuir).
Discharge completed: Finnamore Hill September 19, 1948; Ismalia September 25, 1948; Tweedsmuir Park September 27, 1948.
Suit for Rs. 1,10,323-8-0; trial judge dismissed; High Court dismissed appeal.
6,000 bags coconut from Cochin, 4,733 bags copra and coconuts from Badagara per S.S. Bharatjal (Bharat Lines Ltd.), arrived Bombay mid-September 1948.
Suit filed December 5, 1949, for Rs. 1,05,726-1-6 (part non-delivery, part damage).
Trial court dismissed suit; conceded not filed within one year; High Court dismissed appeal referencing other judgment.

legal_issues.text: Meaning of 'loss' in 3rd clause of paragraph 6 of Art. III: does it include loss from non-delivery of whole or part of goods?
Does the clause prescribe a rule of limitation or extinguish the right to compensation?
Date when goods 'should have been delivered': ship departure date from port?
Are bill of lading clauses requiring notice of claim within one month from vessel arrival void under para 8 of Art. III?

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit barred by 3rd clause para 6 Art. III as not brought within one year after delivery or date goods should have been delivered.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Carriage of Goods by Sea Act, Schedule Art. III para 6 cl. 3

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit barred as no claim made within one month from vessel arrival per bill of lading.

respondent_arguments.text: Art. III para 6 does not apply to non-delivery; 'loss or damage' limited to goods themselves, not non-delivery.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Carriage of Goods by Sea Act, Schedule Art. III para 6

respondent_arguments.text: Date goods should have been delivered is date of final repudiation of liability.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Carriage of Goods by Sea Act, Schedule Art. III para 6 cl. 3; Limitation Act Art. 31

respondent_arguments.text: Clause is rule of limitation, not extinction; extendable by acknowledgment.
Bill of lading one-month notice clause void under Art. III para 8.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Carriage of Goods by Sea Act, Schedule Art. III para 8

court_reasoning.text: 'Loss' includes any loss to shipper/consignee from non-delivery of whole or part of goods, not just physical loss of goods.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Context of Art. III duties includes discharging full quantity; non-delivery causes loss to owner.

court_reasoning.text: Clause extinguishes right and liability, not mere limitation; 'discharged from all liability' means total extinction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: International uniformity; no extension by acknowledgment.

court_reasoning.text: Date goods should have been delivered is when ship leaves port of discharge, as delivery must complete between arrival and departure.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinct from rail contracts; bill of lading specifies vessel.

court_reasoning.text: Bill of lading clauses requiring notice within one month from arrival void as lessening liability contrary to rules.

holdings.text: 'Loss' in Art. III r.6 cl.3 includes non-delivery.
Clause extinguishes liability after one year, not mere limitation.
Date is ship's departure from port.
One-month notice clauses in bills of lading null and void.

precedents_cited.relevance: Give plain meaning to words in international Hague Rules for uniformity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Spens v. The Union Marine Insurance Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Insurance policy total loss; not applicable to carriage non-delivery.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sandeman Sons v. Tyzack and Branfoot Steamship Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Mixed cargo non-delivery is breach; consignee not bound to claim as tenant in common.

statutes_cited.name: Carriage of Goods by Sea Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Carrier liabilities, one-year discharge from liability for loss/damage including non-delivery; voids conflicting bill clauses.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Distinguished; different from Act's extinction provision.

outcome.summary: Civil Appeals Nos. 91 and 92 of 1958 dismissed with costs confirming Bombay High Court dismissal of suits as barred by Art. III r.6 cl.3. Civil Appeal No. 88 of 1956 dismissed as infructuous since decree in favor of respondent final.
outcome.costs: Costs in CAs 91 and 92; one set hearing costs.

key_quotes.text: "In any event the carrier and the ship shall be discharged from all liability in respect of loss or damage unless suit is brought within one year after the delivery of the goods or the date when the goods should have been delivered."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The word loss as used in paragraph 6 is in our opinion intended to mean and include every kind of loss to the owner of the goods-whether it is the whole of the consignment which is not delivered or part of the consignment which is not delivered.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: the date when the goods should have been delivered for the purpose of the third clause of the 6th paragraph of Art. III of the Act is the date when the ship by which the goods were contracted to be carried has left the port.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines starting point for one-year period.
